title: AB 1740
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature of California acknowledges the state's significant economic impact and leadership on national and global issues. They recognize the need for informed policy decisions in rapidly evolving areas, and the surplus of skilled law school graduates in the state that could benefit government work. Only a small percentage of attorneys nationwide work for state governments, limiting the utilization of their expertise. The State of California aims to encourage attorneys to enter public service through a law fellowship program to fill vacancies as older attorneys retire. The California Law Fellowship Program offers licensed attorneys and law school graduates limited-term placements in state government positions, with the goal of promoting permanent public-sector employment. The California Law Fellowship Program, administered by The University of the Pacific McGeorge School of Law, aims to provide post-graduate legal experience and assistance to governmental entities. Preference is given to applicants who are current or former members of the United States military. Fellows are placed in state agencies based on agency acceptance and criteria. The California Law Fellowship Program, administered by The University of the Pacific McGeorge School of Law, aims to provide post-graduate legal experience and assistance to governmental entities. State funds are not used to administer the program. Participation in the program by attorneys, state agencies, or public officials is not considered a gift of public money or thing of value. The program is designed to accomplish the Legislature's intent and defines terms such as "California Law Fellow" and "Qualifying law school graduate." The California Law Fellowship Program provides substantial public benefits to the Legislature. Participants in the program are not considered employees of the Legislature and their services are not considered compensation or gifts to legislators. Placement with the Legislature must be authorized by the appropriate committees. The California Law Fellowship Program requires fellows to be selected and approved by the Senate or Assembly Committee on Rules, and to abide by specified standards and requirements. The director has the authority to lease state-owned real property within the core area for purposes consistent with the Capitol Area Plan. This includes leasing to private parties and public agencies for various uses such as office, residential, parking, and commercial, following specific procedures for leases of five years or more. The director may sell state-owned real property within the Capitol Area Plan area designated for residential and commercial purposes at fair market value to a joint powers authority for development. Sales must not reduce the number of dwelling units for low-income households and existing units on sold land still count towards total units. The director can sell state-owned real property in the Capitol Area Plan area for development to a joint powers authority at fair market value. However, existing residential properties managed by the authority cannot be sold unless it leads to a net increase in residential units on the site. The director cannot sell existing residential properties managed by the joint powers authority in the Capitol Area Plan area unless a deed restriction is recorded requiring the property to be used for residential purposes for at least 45 years. The director's authority in residential leases is limited to the Capitol area. They must ensure tenants are not displaced due to leases after January 1, 1978. The director can enter long-term leases up to 60 years and allow financing through lease assignments. The director must notify key legislative members before executing agreements for state-owned property in Sacramento or Yolo County. The notification must include an economic analysis of the proposed sale and can be determined by the chairman of the committee. The director may sell property in the Capitol Area Plan to the joint powers authority at fair market value to stimulate development. The Capitol Area Development Authority can request these sales with economic analysis, and the director can approve the sale if they agree with the analysis. The Legislature aims to lease residential units in the Capitol area to low or moderate-income individuals below market rates. The director can rent facilities at reduced rates and enter into long-term ground leases for their benefit. Leases of state-owned property in the core area are subject to possessory interest taxes. Proceeds from the sale of state parcels will be deposited into the General Fund, reimbursing the department for any related expenses.
